week2.practice1_html:
What it is

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Create your 5â€‘minute space: Sit or lie down, eyes closed, away from screens. If you can, dim lights and exhale fully before you begin.
  2. Use a simple breath rhythm: Inhale through your nose for 4 counts, hold 1, exhale slowly for 6. Repeat for 10 cycles. Feel your shoulders melt each round.
  3. Add a body scan: Move attention from your scalp to your toes, relaxing each area. If thoughts arise, greet them kindly and return to your breath.
  4. Anchor it daily: Do this once midâ€‘afternoon or right before bed â€” the same time each day trains your body to downshift naturally.

  • Consistency builds momentum â€” one slow breath at a time, Eva. ğŸŒ±

week2.practice3_html:
What it is

Professional Sleeper helps you treat rest as a daily skill â€” learning how to prime your brain and body so every minute of sleep actually restores you. When your deep and REM cycles lengthen naturally, repair hormones and hair-growth signals can finally work uninterrupted.

Why this practice matters for you now

Eva, youâ€™re in the stabilization phase â€” shedding is easing, but your follicles still feel the echo of long-term stress. Because night-shift rhythms and emotional strain are ongoing, improving your sleep efficiency is the â€œbig domino.â€ Mastering this one habit now steadies cortisol, nurtures your new baby hairs, and shortens the time from fragile regrowth to stronger strands.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Anchor your wake-up time. Pick a time you can hold within 15 minutes daily, even on days off. This steady signal tells your circadian rhythm when to raise energy and when to calm it later.
  2. Expose your eyes to natural light. Within 30 minutes of waking, get at least 5â€“10 minutes of outdoor light. Morning daylight resets your internal clock and deepens the next nightâ€™s sleep cycles.
  3. Move early, unwind late. Schedule movement or exercise before 4â€¯p.m. whenever possible; it trains your body to wind down more easily at night.
  4. Dim and disconnect. Two hours before bed, change your lighting to warm tones and stop stressful screen tasks. Let your senses know: â€œday is done.â€
  5. Nap smart. If shift work forces late nights, power-nap for 20â€¯minutes before your shiftâ€”never after sunrise the next dayâ€”to protect nighttime sleep pressure.

  • Watch-outs: Late-night doom scrolling keeps stress hormones high; plug your phone in across the room after your â€œdim and disconnectâ€ window to avoid that trap.
